text: Welcome to the Rusted Garden Homestead. Today I'm going to show you 25 maybe 30 crops that are perennials. You can plant them once and then you can harvest them pretty much every year. Some of them can be harvested for 20 years like asparagus. Other ones maybe you'll get five or 10 years you have to divide or replant. So let's start with herbs. I'm going to cover herbs, vegetables, fruit canes and bushes and fruit trees and nut trees. So it's going to be a lot. I'll put in a timestamp to help you kind of navigate through the parts you want to see. But let's start at the front of my garden. Herbs are wonderful. I'm in Maryland Zone 7 so everything that you're going to see here has been growing in a place that gets 20 degree Fahrenheit winters meaning I get a winter I get a freeze. Typically the cold temperatures get into the 20s it can get below the 20s that's below minus 7 Celsius so the freezing temperatures here generally speaking minus 7 to minus 9 Celsius 20 you know to 32 degrees. Why is that important? Some crops can't take a deep freeze. Some crops need a cold period so I just want to be clear that you guys are modeling the Maryland area. Let's start with the herbs first. Mixed right in here I have oregano. Oregano is a wonderful easy-growing perennial that's all going to be harvested before it flowers. It's going to be left to dry and I'm going to use it as oregano flakes. Right next to it I have sage. Sage is a beautiful perennial bush with purple flowers and you can see that the sage has receded pretty freely. I could dig those up I can move them other places but it doesn't get out of control it doesn't spread like mint or anything like that but these are two wonderful perennial herbs sage and oregano. Inside the main garden I'm growing mint. Mint should be grown in containers it will get out of control you can grow regular mint, spearmint, peppermint and these are two I think five gallon containers these are fabric pots I sell them at my seed shop. Contain the mint it's a beautiful crop that comes back year after year. This is thyme it's just starting to come up I use it as a ground cover you can grow oregano as a ground cover too but thyme can be grown in containers can be grown in your garden or you can just put it in a perennial bed and harvest it you know as you wish. Lavender is a great perennial herb I'm growing it outside my garden next to my nectarine tree really used for the fragrance but it makes a delicious herb to use with chicken dishes. Next to it I have garlic garlic is actually a perennial we tend to harvest the bulb and use it but you can harvest the greenery it's going to come back year after year deer leave it alone you can also harvest some of the bulb drop in another clove and it's just going to you know come back again year after year if you leave the bulb in you're always going to get the greenery a lot of people use that in their saltes in their different cooking dishes garlic's a great addition I am going to go through the herbs first and then I'm going to get to vegetables but use the time stamps to jump to the section of the video you want to watch these are garlic chives so you have regular chives taste more like onion garlic chives flat leaf taste very similar to garlic they both will come back year after year and you can just put them pretty much wherever you want this is my spearmint it's in a framed raised bed and you can see the mint is still breaking out under the birdhouse and in the back right there I'm going to actually dig that up stick it into some containers use it to give away maybe I'll sell it at a plant sale wanted to show you the chives real quick they were all divided up from a place I wanted to move them from and these are going to get dropped back into my garden in different places this is my nursery area I have sage ready to go out into different places time wanted to show you the lemon balm it should be contained like mint it's a free-seater it does come back year after year it's managed much more easily than mints but you do want to keep an eye on it but it's a beautiful lemon fragrance use it for teas I can cook with it I do cook with it it's just a beautiful plant very hearty and it comes back year after year I love rosemary I grow it in containers I grow it in the ground it's all over my property love making this with potatoes rosemary potatoes rosemary chicken absolutely delicious and it just smells and tastes wonderful this is my horse radish plant grows pretty much without care horse radish typically you harvest out parts of the root leave the root in there it's going to come back year after year harvest out parts you can make horse radish but you can also eat the leaves you can use them salt a him down they're not as strong the leaves do not taste like the root the root is what is you know got that classic spicy horseradish taste but I love growing it I have it actually in two places in my garden on the inside where we are now fenced in and outside rabbits leave it alone it does flower you can remove the flowers if you want but the root just continues to grow it's a really hearty plant makes great divisions these are my fruit towers I'm growing strawberries they are perennial we'll get to those shortly wanted to show you the parsley I grow parsley in different pockets of my towers butterflies love them the legs on air caterpillars will eat the leaves and of course you can use them in your own kitchen but I have parsley tucked around all over the place in my gardens we went through the herbs pretty quickly we're going to go through the perennial vegetables more slowly I'm going to talk a little bit about the conditions they like in which they like to live so this is an asparagus plant it is a massive roots I just wanted to show you that asparagus starts out as the spears that we like to eat and then you let it continue to grow it will get four or five feet tall and it will fern out you have to do that so it recharges the root system through the summer and then every year you're going to get asparagus now this was dug up from my other garden it's going to be moved inside I'll show you that place in a second but I just wanted to show you the root system the root system gets massive and you can dig it out just like this replanets somewhere else but it gets really large and it's going to give you asparagus for a good 15 or 20 years let's go over to the main bed here's my main asparagus bed it is now I think on its six year I have two varieties in there purple passion and Mary Washington been harvesting for a good 30 days at this point I'll take a few more of the spears but you have to make sure you leave a good amount of them to grow like I was just saying so that they fern out and then they recharge over the summer so you want to be in an area that drains pretty well you don't want this to sit in water I have a nice long row I don't know it's probably 12 to 18 feet planted these from roots every I don't know I don't know maybe a foot or something like that they're going to creep in fill out and you're going to have a nice hedge of asparagus the plant that you just saw is going to be divided and I'm going to put put it right into there and then there's another open space so let's see if I can just show you how it grows all right here's a good example so it comes up as the spears that we know and I'm going to just reach in and just snap one off I will harvest six or eight of these when I want them for dinner during the harvest period let them grow they continue to get more loose like that then they open up and then some of the other ones are right over there I have two posts at each end some metal wire I'd like this because it doesn't decay and then I weave the growing stalks through there just so that they don't flop over and shade out some of my plants over there but asparagus is a wonderful perennial plant it's going to keep giving for a good 15 to 20 years you can see more of the spears coming up purple passion tends to come up first followed by the Mary Washington pretty well draining soil just FYI my soil is mostly clay so I do prep the area feed them at the end of the season feed them at the beginning of the season compost down the you know right down the line that you see there keep the weeds out that helps them stay intact do their thing you can put down an organic granular if you want if you don't have a lot of compost and maybe feed them with a water soluble in the spring just get to get them growing but if you haven't started in asparagus patch I highly recommend it it's really you know work to get it set up but then you just step back keep it weeded keep them fed and you get asparagus every year this is where growing artichokes and in case you missed it I'm in Maryland zone 7 I get freezing winters typically 20 degrees Fahrenheit sometimes into the teens low temperatures for Celsius about minus 7 a little bit lower generally minus 7 to minus 9 minus 10 Celsius globe artichokes so here in Maryland I need a hardier artichoke so I grow the globe artichokes these are planted last spring I got artichokes from them they came back in the fall this is what they look like I mean they kind of look prehistoric they do need a cold period perennials are good a very based on your winters how cold it gets if you don't get freezing winters you have other crops that are you know perennials that just don't get killed off by the freezes and frost the globe artichokes are pretty hardy you could mulch them they're gonna die back to the ground put down four to six inches of leaf mulch or something over them that will protect them from the cold they're gonna come back look something like this prep the beds very similarly to the asparagus compost at the end of the year compost at the beginning of the year water them in with a water soluble fertilizer they're spaced out I don't know two and a half feet something like that I tend to plant things more closely together but I have four plants one two three four they're absolutely beautiful foliage wise I think they're cool looking but the flowers are these purple sea anemone looking things where the bees actually look like they're swimming through them but you're gonna get plenty of artichokes to harvest or you can just let them bloom and they really do attract bees other pollinators but asparagus artichokes hope I didn't say asparagus artichokes are pretty easy to grow once they're established they're gonna come back year after year this is my rhubarb plant there's actually two in there one I planted this year the main one that you see this is its second year I didn't say it the asparagus and artichokes need full sun rhubarb took me three or four years to find a good place for it it likes Sun but it doesn't want baking 10 hour Sun heating it up it's good to kill it off so this isn't a little bit of a shadier area it will get full Sun from like 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. that's six hours and then it gets more Sun from 4 p.m. on but it's a little bit lower in the sky so it definitely wants a good six hours of sunlight but it doesn't have to be in full Sun you know for the whole day does much better with a little bit of shade so asparagus usually by as root crowns as a root and you drop it in it establishes it can be divided pretty easily the plant right there that is a second year plant from a small root that I bought and I think a big box store talk about that in a second also in here I have a dwarf apple tree we'll be talking about fruit trees and a grapevine so this is my perennial food area where these plants took some work to get them started but now year after year I'm going to get food without having to replant so let's lift up this these leaves here actually and just so you know the leaves themselves are poisonous you cut them off and you actually eat the stalks you make pies and different things out of them so this is the second year plant well let me just restate that this is my second plant that I just planted this year and it will establish and it's gonna look just like this I'll be removing these leaves so some sunlight gets in there this plant is two years old started just like that two years later I mean look how massive it is when it starts to flower you want to remove those I've already done a round of removing the flowers but I'm gonna remove them again and you just want the energy going into the leaves setup was pretty easy again I have clay soil here in Maryland I just made a nice mix I will link in my container soil mixes that I make but basically peat moss some compost loosened up that area dropped in the root watered it in well with the water soluble fertilizer and again at the end of the season beginning of the season I dropped down compost usually just water my plants in with the water soluble you can just see how lovely the rhubarb plant is doing massive leaves don't eat those delicious stalks please subscribe if you're interested in more about how to grow the different plants I'm showing you you can just search my YouTube channel I have over 1500 videos on vegetable gardening and if you're interested in a book I have a new book called growing an edible landscape helps you design the space like I'm showing you today where you're just growing edibles throughout a standard garden and throughout your property alright next we're going to talk about berries fruit canes fruit bushes these are my strawberry towers I'm affiliated with Greenstock Garden they're actually having a big sale through May 12th if you want to check out the video description these are just wonderful ways to grow vertically strawberries this is again my strawberry section look how beautiful these strawberries are they're just starting to get ripe I decided I wanted to concentrate strawberries throughout my garden I have them in towers I mean just massive amounts of strawberries I also grow them in containers lower to the ground which you can see right over here these are 22 gallon containers always in your containers make sure you have holes in them strawberries strawberries strawberries back there strawberries over there you're going to look at the blueberries too I also grow them in the ground in different parts as a ground cover under blueberry bushes blueberry bushes in front of my yard they're really versatile love strawberries so I really upped the amount that I'm growing next we will talk about blueberries these are so easy to grow we can over complicate blueberries you know we're told that they want more acidic soil which is true however blueberries just have shallow roots they don't get more than a foot deep something like that maybe spread out to the width of the canopy so you can just get a water soluble acidic fertilizer water in the base that adds some of the acidity that helps them pull in nutrients but you can see how beautiful my blueberries are I have them on two sides there in fact in their fifth or sixth year you know they're starting to come together I'm gonna have to start doing some pruning I get thousands and thousands of blueberries off of these plants you want to grow blueberries so that you're getting a harvest at different times you have earlier varieties mid-season varieties late-season varieties so you want to mix it up you also want to have multiple varieties it helps with the size and pollination of the blueberries so I probably have six eight different varieties I have early season mid-season late season and if we step right into here you can just see the blueberries go all the way down really easy to grow for feeding you know these are in again more clay soil I just planted them I will throw in some compost and peat moss loosen up the soil but they want to take off water soluble fertilizer that's more acidic just look up acidic water soluble fertilizer once or twice a year that gives them the acidity they need I will scatter down some organic granular but they're doing extremely extremely well and I don't over prune I kind of just let them do their thing and you know I'm rewarded you know beautifully for it stepping over here you can see blackberries these are clumping varieties I think birds took some of the blackberries drop seeds over here but they don't typically move why is that important because raspberries which we'll be talking about can get invasive you want to put them in a place where you know they can kind of spread out and kind of take over these are blackberries blackberries clumping variety which means they stay right in their basic footprint I think these are a Rappahoe variety they don't spread out you know these have been in here for five years and they're just wonderful growers thornless variety so if you can you want to get clumping variety thornless blackberries and they're going to just be super prolific strong year after year as they sometimes might creep out you know I have a cane growing in here I just leave it you know some of them work their way over here I don't really think it was underground because there's some wood in there so it's really difficult for them to move over think the birds drop them but they're easy to just kind of pull up transplant to other places don't take up a big footprint and you're gonna really have endless blackberries and you need maybe three or four plants to get started put them in a place that you can enjoy and watch them grow I really like the foliage I really like the flowers coming into this section I had a black mission fig it can't handle our winters the upper wood dies off the roots stay intact new wood comes up new leaves etc but I'm not getting any figs so after five years that fig tree is not working we go to the figs we're going to go to the Chicago hardy fig just FYI those are eggplant if you get your eggplant devastated with flea beetles seven dust not organic will kill them off in the night and then in the morning rinse it off tried using Captain Jack's dead bug dust that's organic doesn't work as well with the flea beetles my point flea beetles devastate my eggplant if I don't treat them I can't eat them and a lot of people have trouble with egg plant coming or with the flea beetles eating their eggplant leaves these are muscadines these are five-year-old vines plant them like a grape very similar to the grape grow on second-year wood so I hack these back pretty harshly in the spring feed them with the water soluble but once established the roots go down really deep they take in what they need leaves decay feed them they're really low maintenance but absolutely delicious grape like grape like berries on there I highly recommend muscadine's grapes wonderful perennial crops can take really cold winters come back year after year this is a plant that I just put in about a month ago you can see the grape bunches starting to form I'll be pruning it pruning this back a little bit but the idea is for me to grow it up this cattle panel and it's good to cover this whole arch so I'm growing some of the perennial fruits inside my garden gonna show you a couple more grapes that are growing outside the garden they're really easy to grow low maintenance you really just drop it into wherever the planting hole is set up like I've been saying maybe a little bit of compost loosen it up once to be in an area that drains decently just can't be sitting in water but they're extremely hardy they actually grow 10 to 15 foot roots that are going to go really deep into the ground and they're going to pull in all the nutrients they need but I'll give them a big drink of water soluble fertilizer in the spring help them kind of take off give them some nitrogen for the leaves but they do extremely well here in Maryland here's another grapevine this one was the same size as the one you just saw and I put a little you know trellis for it it's mixed in here with the rhubarb dwarf apple trees I was saying earlier and you know it's doing exactly what I want you can prune these back pretty harshly they're gonna stay contained the vines that I'm keeping on there to what you see there I think it's gonna highly recommend them let me show you another vine and then we'll move on to raspberries this is another part of my garden you can see I have a lot of fruit trees this is a concord grape growing along plants do fine with that they just don't want to be in sitting water sitting water fills the air pockets around the roots causes root rot the plant suffocates so the water just has to drain away in behind me is the west this is supposed to be a semi dwarf tree I'm keeping it contained it's not going to cast shadow onto my garden it's outside the main garden and I wanted it there for a little bit of shade for right along this area where I grow peppers because come July it gets really hot here a little bit of shade is going to help them out they still get light as the sun tracks around but you can strategically place your trees so they don't create shade or they do create a little bit of shade in your main growing area I have fruit trees inside my garden this is another nectarine tree you can see some of the nectarines some sort of weird leaf disease which is great I'll have to figure out what that is again nectarines do really well I mean just look at all the nectarines in there now this tree all of my trees are actually bought at Home Depot Lowes or Sun Nursery they were all about five feet tall six feet tall at least three years old the trees here have been in the ground this is the third year this is supposed to be dwarf I have to cut it back a whole lot again another nectarine tree a plum tree we'll be focusing more on those when I go outside of this main garden but I just wanted to show you that you can grow them sort of in raised beds this again was supposed to be semi dwarf we have to go and cut it back grow them an all kinds of different ways add them to the fruit garden basically the southern suns over there the western suns over here the shadows to the trees are going to be cast outside the garden so you can plant with the strategy and put some of them inside your fence line if you need to protect them from deer and other animals I only have one nut tree on my property this is a halls hearty almond which I really do recommend doesn't come in any kind of dwarf size so it is going to get really tall that's you know over 20 feet tall I think the almonds are on there I get so many almonds the squirrels tend to eat some of them but it's really prolific so you can see the almonds all through there it has beautiful flowers too here's maybe a better example of the almonds but the halls hearty almond is a wonderful tree it's over here more to the edge of my property the sunlight comes through you can see that but it's not going to really cast any shadow into my garden because I knew that it was going to get really tall just here's some more of the almonds halls hearty almond I highly recommend that so when you're growing trees that are going to be 18 20 30 feet tall make sure you place them in a place where they're not going to drop shade onto your main garden here's a quick look of a dwarf peach tree it's on the inside of my other garden planted right in the center of a raised bed that's the bed that I'm going to be putting a strawberry plants into lots of peaches staying about it'll be somewhere between 8 and maybe 12 feet tall but it's going to stay nice and small some mild pruning and this will be loaded with peaches without you know having a massive tree this is pretty much my orchard these are some pear trees which will get to in a second and then I have five trees out here I have a cherry in the front peach and plums another cherry tree too and plenty of space dwarf trees semi dwarf trees you don't have to worry so much about having a great distance between them these trees are all pruned they're supposed to be semi dwarf they're pretty tall but they're not going to get 25 40 feet tall well one of the plums is on its way but sometimes you buying more at a quality nursery you can make sure you get the right type of plant I think some of these semi dwarfs aren't semi dwarfs they're full-sized trees anyway this is kind of the spacing I have they get at least eight hours of sun realistically they're probably getting a good 10 hours worth of sun you want a lot of sun for your fruit trees and my biggest tip it's a really prune the inside of the canopy for air here's one of my plum trees it's doing really well heavily pruned on the inside again of the canopy there's some of the plums starting to come out already last year they were infested with aphids so far so good there's no insect damage I'm inspecting these very closely here's another plum tree and you can see just all the plums on their fruit trees are really rewarding there's a little bit of a learning curve to learn how to manage them you know I'm not an expert pruner like the branch right there should probably come out but I pruned the inside out a whole lot you see new branches come in this tree it's doing pretty well loaded with fruit you know I'm very happy about that plum trees another great addition to your garden cherry trees are wonderful to add to the garden the crows do like the cherries my other fruit tends to be left alone I just have to pick them when they're actually ripe they're pretty good when they get overripe and they're really sweet that's when the crows like to roll in this is a cherry tree that produced really well last year but it's even producing more now I mean look at all these cherries they're just all over the place I'm really excited to see that that means there'll be room to share with the crows and I'm going to get a lot of them I mean I can see all the cherries going all the way up the branches now this is a good probably 18 feet tall pruned a lot to remove a lot of the inner branches keep that airflow going you really want to manage disease issues all my trees will be getting spray with an anti-fungal this week but they're looking pretty good as far as feeding once established that year I don't do much I just let them you know take from the soil I will put mulch grass clippings and stuff around the base that helps provide some food but I don't do much else all right let's go into the picket fence and I'll show you the peach trees I'm sorry the pear trees we're looking at the southern sky so the trees all in this line just get a ton of sunlight and actually probably don't have to go in there just going to show you so last year struggling a little bit getting the pears prune them back this tree is loaded with pears now I mean that is just wonderful to see sometimes when you're pruning and cutting back you learn what to remove it helps bring out more flowers the following year just look at all the pears on here this is actually this is pretty impressive I didn't look at this tree yet really this year and it is just loaded with pears it's wonderful this might be a Bartlett I have a couple different varieties like I was saying different tree types tree varieties like mixes of different types of trees so I have like 12 different variety apple trees three different kinds of pears this one's loaded too so the pruning actually really did help bring out segments.text: Welcome to the Rusted Garden Homestead. Today I'm going to show you 25 maybe 30
crops that are perennials. You can plant them once and then you can harvest them
pretty much every year. Some of them can be harvested for 20 years like asparagus.
Other ones maybe you'll get five or 10 years you have to divide or replant. So
let's start with herbs. I'm going to cover herbs, vegetables, fruit canes and
bushes and fruit trees and nut trees. So it's going to be a lot. I'll put in a
timestamp to help you kind of navigate through the parts you want to see. But
let's start at the front of my garden. Herbs are wonderful. I'm in Maryland Zone
7 so everything that you're going to see here has been growing in a place that
gets 20 degree Fahrenheit winters meaning I get a winter I get a
freeze. Typically the cold temperatures get into the 20s it can get below the
20s that's below minus 7 Celsius so the freezing temperatures here generally
speaking minus 7 to minus 9 Celsius 20 you know to 32 degrees. Why is that
important? Some crops can't take a deep freeze. Some crops need a cold period so
I just want to be clear that you guys are modeling the Maryland area. Let's
start with the herbs first. Mixed right in here I have oregano. Oregano is a
wonderful easy-growing perennial that's all going to be harvested before it
flowers. It's going to be left to dry and I'm going to use it as oregano
flakes. Right next to it I have sage. Sage is a beautiful perennial bush with
purple flowers and you can see that the sage has receded pretty
freely. I could dig those up I can move them other places but it doesn't get
out of control it doesn't spread like mint or anything like that but these are
two wonderful perennial herbs sage and oregano. Inside the main garden I'm
growing mint. Mint should be grown in containers it will get out of control
you can grow regular mint, spearmint, peppermint and these are two I think five
gallon containers these are fabric pots I sell them at my seed shop. Contain the
mint it's a beautiful crop that comes back year after year. This is thyme it's
just starting to come up I use it as a ground cover you can grow oregano as a
ground cover too but thyme can be grown in containers can be grown in your
garden or you can just put it in a perennial bed and harvest it you know
as you wish. Lavender is a great perennial herb I'm growing it outside
my garden next to my nectarine tree really used for the fragrance but it makes
a delicious herb to use with chicken dishes. Next to it I have garlic garlic is
actually a perennial we tend to harvest the bulb and use it but you can harvest
the greenery it's going to come back year after year deer leave it alone you can
also harvest some of the bulb drop in another clove and it's just going to
you know come back again year after year if you leave the bulb in you're
always going to get the greenery a lot of people use that in their saltes in
their different cooking dishes garlic's a great addition I am going to go through
the herbs first and then I'm going to get to vegetables but use the time stamps
to jump to the section of the video you want to watch these are garlic chives
so you have regular chives taste more like onion garlic chives flat leaf
taste very similar to garlic they both will come back year after year and you
can just put them pretty much wherever you want this is my spearmint it's in
a framed raised bed and you can see the mint is still breaking out under the
birdhouse and in the back right there I'm going to actually dig that up stick it
into some containers use it to give away maybe I'll sell it at a plant sale
wanted to show you the chives real quick they were all divided up from a place I
wanted to move them from and these are going to get dropped back into my
garden in different places this is my nursery area I have sage ready to go
out into different places time wanted to show you the lemon balm it should be
contained like mint it's a free-seater it does come back year after year it's
managed much more easily than mints but you do want to keep an eye on it but it's
a beautiful lemon fragrance use it for teas I can cook with it I do cook with
it it's just a beautiful plant very hearty and it comes back year after year I
love rosemary I grow it in containers I grow it in the ground it's all over my
property love making this with potatoes rosemary potatoes rosemary chicken
absolutely delicious and it just smells and tastes wonderful this is my horse

do not taste like the root the root is what is you know got that classic spicy
horseradish taste but I love growing it I have it actually in two places in my

alone it does flower you can remove the flowers if you want but the root

caterpillars will eat the leaves and of course you can use them in your own

massive roots I just wanted to show you that asparagus starts out as the spears
that we like to eat and then you let it continue to grow it will get four or
five feet tall and it will fern out you have to do that so it recharges the

now this was dug up from my other garden it's going to be moved inside
I'll show you that place in a second but I just wanted to show you the root
system the root system gets massive and you can dig it out just like this
replanets somewhere else but it gets really large and it's going to give

here's my main asparagus bed it is now I think on its six year I have two

that they fern out and then they recharge over the summer so you want to be in an

long row I don't know it's probably 12 to 18 feet planted these from roots
every I don't know I don't know maybe a foot or something like that they're

the plant that you just saw is going to be divided and I'm going to put put it right

some metal wire I'd like this because it doesn't decay and then I weave the

some of my plants over there but asparagus is a wonderful perennial plant
it's going to keep giving for a good 15 to 20 years you can see more of the

keep the weeds out that helps them stay intact do their thing you can put down
